section.name: Building with Eclipse
section.p: This chapter is meant as a guide for setting up and managing a debugging environment for Hippo ECM inside Eclipse. By the time you have finished reading you will be able to run and debug every aspect of Hippo ECM from within Eclipse. As a follow up you might look\ into some Eclipse tips&tricks for how to keep up with the most exiting version of Hippo ECM: The trunk!
section.div: NOTE: Hippo ECM is a large project with many subprojects, setting up and managing it in Eclipse is a non-trivial task and can be very error-prone. If not done correctly this can become a very frustrating experience where most of the time you are waiting on eclipse and chasing rabbits. The steps and best practices outlined here will enable you to avoid this frustration, if follow them you will find that developing Hippo ECM with Eclipse can actually be very easy.
section.p:
Please note that most of the loopholes you are going to jump through when following these steps are workarounds for difficulties due to the fact that Maven is our leading buildsystem and not Eclipse. Setting up Eclipse for Hippo ECM means mimicking the Maven build inside Eclipse: for each step the Maven build does create the Hippo ECM artefacts (Ear, War and Jar files), a corresponding step for Eclipse should be set up. The upside is that, precicely because eclipse has it's own build system, the effects of code changes can be seen very rapidly. Simple code changes can even be done on a running application and don't need a restart.
From the point of view of Hippo ECM Eclipse is 'just another IDE', if you don't like going through all this you might consider looking into NetBeans which integrates extremely nice with the Maven build, no mimicking and no weird workarounds. The downside is that, precicely because it directly depends on the Maven build, seeing the effects of code changes can take longer than in Eclipse.

section.name: Prepare
section.p: Follow all steps documented on the Building with Maven page. Don't continue with the instructions on this page before you have seen a running application using just Maven.

div.p: NOTE: Do not do the initial checkout of the source tree from within Eclipse, use the command line SVN client.

NOTE: The checked out project directory should not be inside your Eclipse workspace directory. For the rest of this chapter ~/hippo-ecm is the directory where the sources are checked out and ~/workspace is the Eclipse workspace directory.

subsection.name: Tune your Eclipse memory settings
subsection.p: Add some memory flags to the eclipse -vmargs startup argument.

ul.li: Set the heap size to at least 512M by adding something like -Xms512m -Xmx512m
Set the permSpace size to at least 128M by adding something like -XX:MaxPermSize=128M

section.p: Start Eclipse, it is strongly advised to start with a clean workspace. Use the eclipse update manager (Help -> Software Updates -> Find and Install) to install the following eclipse plugins:

subsection.name: Subversion
subsection.p: In the 'Select features to install' step only select the following two features:

ol.li: Subversive SVN Team Provider Plugin -> SVN Team Provider <version number>
Subversive Client Libraries -> SVNKit <version number> Implementation

li.p: Apply changes and close the dialog

subsection.name: JPOX
subsection.p:
In the 'Select features to install' step only select 'JPOX Eclipse Plugin'
In the eclipse preferences dialog:

li.p: Uncheck 'Use project classpath when running tools' (some versions have it below submenu 'JPOX -> General')
Add the following jars to the classpath: You can find these jars in your local maven repository if you have followed the instructions on the Building with Maven page.
Select JPOX -> Enhancer and enter 'BCEL' in the the 'Class Enhancer' field.

section.name: Create eclipse projects, part one
section.div: NOTE: Make sure that there is no .project file in the toplevel (hippo-ecm) directory before proceding. If there is one the eclipse import projects wizard will fail.
section.p: Use the maven eclipse plugin to generate eclipse project files:
section.source: ~/> cd hippo-ecm ~/hippo-ecm> mvn clean ~/hippo-ecm> mvn [-o] eclipse:eclipse
section.p: The first time you run this command it will take extremely long, do it right before lunch kind of long. This is in part because it will attempt to download everything including sources and javadocs. On later runs you could add a -o (offline) flag to prevent downloading the sources, this makes it a lot faster.

li.p: Run the import project wizard: File -> Import -> General -> Existing Projects into Workspace
All hippo-ecm projects should be listed

section.name: Create eclipse projects, part two
section.p: The maven build extensively uses WAR overlays which unfortunately aren't fully supported by the maven eclipse plugin. Therefore you need to manually fix the eclipse projects before you can proceed.

subsection.name: Resources
subsection.p: The maven build overlays the skin and xinha plugins over the final package-war by copying the skin and xinha files to the package/war/src/main/webapp directory. Manually copying these files in order to fix the package-war project for eclipse can be very painful because it needs to be done every time when a skin or xinha file changes. A much better way is to use symbolic links.

li.p: Although it is not possible to create symbolic links with the tools that are provided by default by Windows, they do exist. One of the Microsoft supplied tools for this is junction. With this tool, the symbolic links can be created as:
li.source: C:\hippo-ecm> cd package\war\src\main\webapp C:\hippo-ecm\package\war\src\main\webapp> junction skin ..\..\..\..\skin\src\main\webapp C:\hippo-ecm\package\war\src\main\webapp> junction xinha ..\..\..\..\..\addon\xinha\src\main\webapp C:\hippo-ecm\package\war\src\main\webapp> cd ..\..\..\..\.. C:\hippo-ecm> cd addon\xinha\src\main\webapp\xinha\plugins C:\hippo-ecm\addon\xinha\src\main\webapp\xinha\plugins> junction AutoSave ..\..\..\..\..\webResources\xinha\plugins\AutoSave C:\hippo-ecm\addon\xinha\src\main\webapp\xinha\plugins> junction CustomLinker ..\..\..\..\..\webResources\xinha\plugins\CustomLinker

~/> cd hippo-ecm/package/war/src/main/webapp ~/hippo-ecm/package/war/src/main/webapp> ln -s ../../../../skin/src/main/webapp/ skin ~/hippo-ecm/package/war/src/main/webapp> ln -s ../../../../../addon/xinha/src/main/webapp/ xinha ~/hippo-ecm/package/war/src/main/webapp> cd ../../../../.. ~/hippo-ecm> cd addon/xinha/src/main/webapp/xinha/plugins ~/hippo-ecm/addon/xinha/src/main/webapp/xinha/plugins> ln -s ../../../../../webResources/xinha/plugins/AutoSave/ AutoSave ~/hippo-ecm/addon/xinha/src/main/webapp/xinha/plugins> ln -s ../../../../../webResources/xinha/plugins/CustomLinker/ CustomLinker

li.p: Right-click the hippo-ecm-package-war project in the package explorer

subsection.name: Test resource folders
subsection.p: The maven-eclipse-plugin creates source folders for test resources. These can interfere with the initialization of the repository, so they should be removed from the classpath.

li.p: Right-click the hippo-ecm-repository-engine project in the package explorer.

section.name: Run
section.p: Select the 'Arguments' tab and add to 'VM Arguments':
(Optional) Select the 'Common' tab and check 'Run' and 'Debug' under 'display in favorites menu'

You can now debug the application within Eclipse: Set a breakpoint in the constructor of org.hippoecm.frontend.Home, run the Jetty launcher in debug mode, open your browser and go to http://localhost:8080
